question.body: One of the most prominent features in our courses are Learn By Doing activities. These activities give you the opportunity to practice a skill or better understand a new concept. Which of the following do you think is true about Learn By Doing question types in this course?

multiple_choice.choice: They may introduce you to new aspects of a concept that you are currently learning.
They can be skipped if you think you already know the answer.
Only the question and correct answer matters in a Learn By Doing.
They are only presented at the end of a chunk of content to evaluate your knowledge of the presented concept.

response.feedback: Correct. Often Learn By Doing questions not only test your knowledge of a concept; at the same time they expand that knowledge and/or provide specific examples to practice the concept in context.
Incorrect. Learn by Doing question types should never be skipped because they might offer additional information to be learned or expand on a concept.

Incorrect. You can learn something by reviewing all of the hints and feedback in the question. Often the list of answer choices for a Learn By Doing are carefully selected based on common misconceptions about the question.

Incorrect. Learn By Doing question types are usually found right after a presented concept, so that you can practice the concept as you learn it, and these question types are scaffolded to give support “as needed” by providing tailored hints and feedback. Did I Get This activity types are usually presented at the end of a chunk of content, so that you can self-assess.

part.hint: Learn By Doing question types are presented in-context.
The intent of these activities is often to let you explore many different aspects and details of new concepts that you may not have otherwise experienced.
“Learn By Doing” suggests you might learn something at the same time you are doing something.
